abstract: <jats:p>Genetic imputation has become standard practice in modern genetic studies. However, several important issues have not been adequately addressed including the utility of study‐specific reference, performance in admixed populations, and quality for less common (minor allele frequency [<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MAF</jats:styled-content>] 0.005–0.05) and rare (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MAF</jats:styled-content> < 0.005) variants. These issues only recently became addressable with genome‐wide association studies (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content>) follow‐up studies using dense genotyping or sequencing in large samples of non‐<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropean individuals. In this work, we constructed a study‐specific reference panel of 3,924 haplotypes using <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>mericans in the Women's Health Initiative (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">WHI</jats:styled-content>) genotyped on both the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>etabochip and the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>ffymetrix 6.0 <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content> platform. We used this reference panel to impute into 6,459 <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">WHI SNP H</jats:styled-content>ealth <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>ssociation <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">R</jats:styled-content>esource (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SHARe</jats:styled-content>) study subjects with only <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content> genotypes. Our analysis confirmed the imputation quality metric <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">Rsq</jats:styled-content> (estimated <jats:italic>r</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>, specific to each <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>) as an effective post‐imputation filter. We recommend different <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">Rsq</jats:styled-content> thresholds for different <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MAF</jats:styled-content> categories such that the average (across <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNPs</jats:styled-content>) <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">Rsq</jats:styled-content> is above the desired dosage r<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> (squared <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>earson correlation between imputed and experimental genotypes). With a desired dosage r<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> of 80%, 99.9% (97.5%, 83.6%, 52.0%, 20.5%) of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNPs</jats:styled-content> with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MAF</jats:styled-content> > 0.05 (0.03–0.05, 0.01–0.03, 0.005–0.01, and 0.001–0.005) passed the post‐imputation filter. The average dosage r<jats:sup>2</jats:sup> for these <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNPs</jats:styled-content> is 94.7%, 92.1%, 89.0%, 83.1%, and 79.7%, respectively. These results suggest that for <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>mericans imputation of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">M</jats:styled-content>etabochip <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNPs</jats:styled-content> from <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content> data, including low frequency <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNPs</jats:styled-content> with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MAF</jats:styled-content> 0.005–0.05, is feasible and worthwhile for power increase in downstream association analysis provided a sizable reference panel is available.</jats:p>

title: Genotype Imputation of <scp>M</scp>etabochip<scp>SNPs</scp> Using a Study‐Specific Reference Panel of ∼4,000 Haplotypes in <scp>A</scp>frican <scp>A</scp>mericans From the Women's Health Initiative
